Description.val:
This line funds modifications to avionics equipment used for fleet training exercises by opposing forces and adversary forces used during counter surface and attack training scenarios and fleet exercises. The overall goal is to accurately simulate known and postulated electronic attack capability and tactics of radar and jammer threats expected to be encountered during operational deployments. Operation systems under OSIP 119-83 were divested prior to FY 2002. 

Current equipment, AN/ALQ-167, AN/AST-6 and follow-on AN/AST-9 pod variants are carried aboard F/A-18, Lear Jet, Kfir (F-21), Hawker/Hunter (F-58), Gulfstream (G-1) and F-16 aircraft. Internal aircraft installation variants, AN/ULQ-21/24 are used in targets and the AN/ALQ-237 rack installation is used on F-5N. The remaining quantities of 20 legacy AST-6 pods are no longer repairable.  These pods are being augmented/replaced by AN/AST-9 and will be flown until the end of their operational service life. FY 2010- FY 2012 and prior years' Below Threshold Reprogramming (BTR) funding procured 34 Advanced Digital Radio Frequency Memory (DRFM) systems to address adversary forces training requirements per Naval Strike Air Warfare Center Urgent Operational Need Statement.  The adversary systems (aka HAVE ALL-Filthy Bader) comprised 19 ALQ-167 pods, 12 F-5 rack installs and 3 ACaP pods procured in coordination with the United States Air Force (USAF).  As of FY 2014, one legacy ALQ-167 pod per year from the remaining pods inventory will be converted to DRFM configuration.

Adversary Electronic Attack (EA) DRFM program systems completed deliveries in FY 2013 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) in FY 2010 - 2012. As a result, all subsequent installations are modifications to fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements.  FY 2013 shifted program focus from full production to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the required engineering and logistics to accomplish these upgrades in future years.

Name.@footnote: Increase in FYDP provides the logistics support required to support the aging ALQ-167 Pod variants and AST-9 Pod variants.
Increase in FYDP provides the engineering support required to support the aging ALQ-167 Pod variants and AST-9 Pod variants.

1.  Adversary Electronic Attack (EA) Digital Radio Frequency Memory (DRFM) program systems completed deliveries in FY13 as funded under the Abbreviated Acquisition Plan (AAP) for FY10-12. As a result, all future installations are modifications to Fleet systems based on the EA DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger requirements.  In FY 2013, the program shifted focus from full production to the Filthy Badger modification. Cost increases in FYDP supports unique modifications, hardware and Fleet Training.
Cost increases in FYDP supports unique modifications, hardware and Fleet Training.

Description.val:
This line funds modifications to avionics equipment used for fleet training exercises by opposing forces and adversary forces aircraft in threat representative electronic attack scenarios. The overall goal is to accurately simulate known and postulated electronic warfare capability and tactics of radar and jammer threats expected to be encountered during operational deployments. Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP 119-83) Fleet Electronic Warfare Support Group (FEWSG) equipment includes AN/AST-6 and AN/AST-9 radar simulators for opposing forces aircraft as well as AN/ALQ-167, AN/ALQ-237 and AN/ULQ-21 radar jammers for both opposing forces and adversary forces aircraft. 

Background - AN/ALQ-167, AN/AST-6 and AN/AST-9 are pod configured systems carried aboard Kfir (F-21), Hawker Hunter (F-58), Lear Jets, F-16N and F/A-18 C/D/E/F aircraft. AN/ULQ-21 and AN/ALQ-237 are internally mounted systems carried aboard Gulfstream (G1) and F-5N, respectively. AN/AST-6 pods are legacy assets being replaced with AN/AST-9 radar simulators. AN/AST-6 systems will be flown until the end of their operational service life to fill the continued shortfall in electronic attack systems capacity and capability. In FY 2013 Adversary Electronic Attack Abbreviated Acquisition (AAP) program completed deliveries of 34 Advanced Digital Radio Frequency Memory (DRFM) systems in response to Commander Fleet Forces Urgent Operational Needs Statement (UONS) to quickly deliver and augment electronic attack training capacity and to mitigate some level of capability shortfall. The Adversary DRFM based systems included - 19 AN/ALQ-167 pods, 12 AN/ALQ-237 internal mounted systems and 3 ACaP pods.

Current status: Following rapid delivery of the 34 AAP systems, program focus is on establishing the required maintenance and sparing posture to support this acquisition. As a result of completed deliveries, all future installations are modifications to Adversary DRFM systems based on the electronic attack DRFM Roadmap for Filthy Badger classified program requirements. In FY13, the program shifted focus from full production to the Filthy Badger modification schedule and support of the engineering and logistics to accomplish these upgrades in future years and further directed for no additional legacy ALQ-167 pod conversions.
